channel.title: Database and logging into the client[please help]
channel.description:
hey guys so i seem to have a problem here, hopefully i can get it solved.
I have a register script that adds a game character into the database it crypts the password in md5, it also converts the user to long. my problem is that when I try to login then it tells me I have invalid username and password when it is correct. What else needs to be done here anyone???

item.title: Database and logging into the client[please help]
item.dc:creator: @matty_matt matty matt
item.description:
@matty_matt wrote:

my msn is actually redzero13@hotmail.com

im using i believe it is darkquest

edit: i actually think it has something to do with how i save the username in the user value in the database.

EDIT: If someone can please add me on msn messenger and help me through this i would appreciate it alot, as i have put days worth in trying to figure this out and i cannot.

Read full topic
item.source: Database and logging into the client[please help]

item.title: Database and logging into the client[please help]
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

I wasn’t really talking about the collation of the database table so much as what’s actually passing into the hash function.

For example, you might be hashing a UTF-8 string in Java but perhaps you’re hashing a ISO-8859 string in PHP (I’m assuming that’s the default character encoding used in PHP, having read this: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9351694/setting-php-default-encoding-to-utf-8).

Anyway, a hash is ultimately preformed on the byte array, not the resulting string. This means that two different byte arrays, when processed with two different encodings, can output the same textual string - but the resulting hashes wouldn’t match up.

Read full topic
item.source: Database and logging into the client[please help]

item.title: Database and logging into the client[please help]
item.dc:creator: @D.Shark D.Shark
item.description:
@D.Shark wrote:

Which source are you using? In some of the RSCD sources, you may be encrypting it etc right… but it reads from tables in a strange way. I don’t recall exactly how, but for e.g. updating just the players table won’t let you login, it’ll also be synched to the users or some shit. So if you make a duplicate account and use the same encrypted password in the database for a row your inserting and STILL can’t login, then there’s more to it than what meets the eye.

That’s in some source I used though, I guess you can just check the server side code also to see exactly where it reads etc…

When helping someone I ended up checking what the shitty punbb registration page does, and that helped me realize the issue, just keep looking.

Read full topic
item.source: Database and logging into the client[please help]

item.title: Database and logging into the client[please help]
item.dc:creator: @matty_matt matty matt
item.description:
@matty_matt wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:9, topic:533895”]It could be the encoding used for the strings at the time you has them.
For example, hashing the word ‘Derp’ would give you different results if it were ASCII and UTF-8 encoded.[/quote]
which encoding is used with rscd? nvm it is latin
ok now i have added a character and the password that was saved into the database i took it and used a md5 cracker and it came out with the correct password, so it is saving it correctly.
edit: i used utf and latin and they both gave me the same password when cracked…
Any other ideas please… i also have msn messenger… redzer013@hotmail.com

Read full topic
item.source: Database and logging into the client[please help]

item.title: Database and logging into the client[please help]
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

It could be the encoding used for the strings at the time you has them.
For example, hashing the word ‘Derp’ would give you different results if it were ASCII and UTF-8 encoded.

item.source: Database and logging into the client[please help]

item.title: Database and logging into the client[please help]
item.dc:creator: @matty_matt matty matt
item.description:
@matty_matt wrote:

Lothy:

MD5 has long been considered insecure. Use a newer hashing algorithm like SHA-256 or SHA-512.

thanks i will keep that in mind…

but now i have imported database and i can login my client with the character that are already in the database, but not when i create a new one.

Im wondering if someone could point me in the right direction to login with my new character i put in the database.
when i register a new character:
It does hash the user, it adds username in string, and it adds password in md5 just the same as the other character in the database that work and do log in the client.
My problem is i get invalid username or password. on the loginserver prompt nothing.
thanks in advance to who helps

Read full topic
